message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The KCNQ1 gene mutation causing a defect in slow voltage-gated potassium channels is associated with congenital long QT syndrome. Therefore, the most likely electrocardiogram finding would be prolongation of the QT interval. The other options are less likely to be associated with this genetic mutation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a mutation in the KCNQ1 gene causing a defect in slow voltage-gated potassium channels, which is associated with Long QT syndrome. An electrocardiogram will show prolongation of the QT interval. The other options are not associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mutation in the KCNQ1 gene and the presentation of recurrent dizziness and syncope suggest long QT syndrome. Therefore, the electrocardiogram is most likely to show prolongation of the QT interval. Pseudo-right bundle branch block, slurred upstroke of the QRS complex, and absence of P waves are not associated with long QT syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mutation in the KCNQ1 gene causes a defect in slow voltage-gated potassium channels leading to long QT syndrome. Therefore, the electrocardiogram is most likely to show prolongation of the QT interval. The other options are not typically associated with long QT syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The KCNQ1 gene mutation is associated with Long QT syndrome, which can cause syncope and sudden cardiac death. Prolongation of the QT interval is the characteristic ECG finding in Long QT syndrome. Therefore, the answer is (D).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mutation in the KCNQ1 gene causes Jervell and Lange-Nielsen Syndrome, characterized by sensorineural deafness and prolonged QT interval on electrocardiogram. None of the other options are associated with this syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The genetic mutation causing a defect in potassium channels suggests Long QT syndrome, which can lead to syncope and sensorineural deafness. Prolongation of the QT interval is a characteristic electrocardiogram finding in Long QT syndrome. The other options such as pseudo-right bundle branch block, slurred upstroke of the QRS complex, or absence of P waves are not associated with Long QT syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome, which is a genetic disorder that affects hearing and heart function. The mutation in the KCNQ1 gene causes a defect in slow voltage-gated potassium channels, which can lead to prolongation of the QT interval on electrocardiograms. Therefore, (D) is the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The gene mutation causing a defect in slow voltage-gated potassium channels indicates a possibility of long QT syndrome. Prolongation of the QT interval is a hallmark of long QT syndrome. The other options are not associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mutation in the KCNQ1 gene causes a defect in slow voltage-gated potassium channels, which can cause Long QT syndrome. Therefore, an electrocardiogram of this patient is most likely to show prolongation of the QT interval. The other options are not associated with this condition.
